Between encounters, the heroes often explore dungeons or other environments. Time is more flexible during exploration than in encounters and is measured in 10-minute intervals or more. You tell the players what happens, and you can skip over any parts of their travels that aren’t interesting!

Set a Party Order

When the group starts exploring, let the players decide among themselves where in the group their heroes are while exploring. This order can determine who gets attacked first when enemies or traps threaten from various directions. It’s up to you to determine the specifics of who gets targeted based on the situation.

When an encounter starts, the group usually remains in the same general formation. With the heroes' input, decide their positions when you put the tokens on the scene. If they get the drop on their enemies or detect a hazard in advance, they can move around as they see fit before dealing with it.

Exploration Activities

While the party explores, each player who wants to do something beyond just traveling chooses an exploration activity for their character. Players usually choose from the default activities, but there’s no need for them to memorize the exploration activities and use them exactly. Instead, when your players want to do something in addition to simply traveling, have them describe the basics of what they're attempting to do, such as “I’m searching for hazards” or “I’m keeping my shield ready in case we’re attacked.” As the GM, you find the best exploration activity to match their description and describe the effects of that activity. Some exploration activities limit how fast a character can travel and be effective:

@Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.IE2nThCmoyhQA0Jn]{Avoid Notice} @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.cYtYKa1gDEl7y2N0]{Defend} @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.Yb0C1uLzeHrVLl7a]{Detect Magic} @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.JuqmIAnkL9hVGai8]{Hustle} @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.EwgTZBWsc8qKaViP]{Investigate} @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.kV3XM0YJeS2KCSOb]{Scout} @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.TiNDYUGlMmxzxBYU]{Search} @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.fJImDBQfqfjKJOhk]{Sense Direction}

If a player wants to do something not on the list of exploration activities above, you can let them if they could reasonably do it while walking around. If the activity is similar to an action someone could use in an encounter, it usually consists of a single action repeated roughly 10 times per minute. You might find that a player wants to do something equivalent to spending 3 actions every 6 seconds (18 times per minute), just like they would in combat. However, heroes can’t maintain that level of exertion in exploration mode without getting exhausted. They can do so in combat only because combat lasts such a short time.

Narrating Exploration

As the group explores, describe the sights, sounds, and sensations. Encourage the other players to have their heroes truly explore, and reward their curiosity. The things they try to do in exploration mode show you what they’re interested in and what they consider important. As you play, you should get a good feel for what intrigues certain players, and you can add more of those things to your adventures or emphasize these points in published adventures.

Activities like Detect Magic, Investigate, and Search can tip off a player that something is odd about an area. But that doesn't mean they know exactly what it is! Instead, use these as a starting point for a roleplaying scene. For instance, if a character finds something magical with detect magic, the party likely still needs to stop and look at the surroundings in more detail to figure out what it is.

Similarly, if a character got a 22 on their Perception check to Search while traveling through an area containing a trap that needs a DC 20 to detect it, you should tell the player that their character noticed a trap in the area, and you can give a rough idea of the trap’s location and nature. The party needs to stop and examine the area more to learn specifics about the trap

Locations.name: Locations
Locations.text:
Bring out the players’ curiosity through memorable settings that include mysterious and fantastical locations for the heroes to visit! Exploring each location should be a treat in itself, not just a step the players must complete to get from one fight to the next. As you create a locale, picture it in your mind’s eye, and write down details you can include as you narrate the game. Describing decorations, natural landmarks, wildlife, peculiar smells, and even temperature changes makes a place feel more real.

Beyond monsters and loot, your locations can include challenges based on the environment, from weather conditions like blizzards to puzzles, traps, or other hazards. These challenges should suit your adventure’s location: walls of brambles in a castle ruin overrun with vegetation, pools of acid in a cursed swamp, or magical traps in the tomb of a paranoid wizard. Consult the handouts for @UUID[.AJZOnRliAzq7nbDM], @UUID[.mhP6TyghfJ6AE3ia], and @UUID[.f82BLxCvoOGIzQ7U] for inspiration.

Drawing a Map.name: Drawing a Map
Drawing a Map.text:
Many adventures focus on a single location or dungeon. Once you know your adventure's story, you can start drawing the map to make it easier to keep track of where everything is. It's best to draw the map on a sheet of graph paper first, with each square on the graph paper representing a 5-foot square. Then, when you run the game, you can use a map with a 1-inch grid (where every square inch represents a 5-foot square).

When you first draw your map, you should use a pencil so you can make changes easily. You can also jot down notes for each room as they come to you, like "guard post" or "spider nest."

Sample Map

Here you can see the sketch used to make the first level of the "Menace under Otari" map! Below it is a set of symbols you can use to represent common features found in most dungeons: doors, stairs, traps, pillars, and more.

Mapping Tips

• Avoid Empty Rooms: Don’t add too many empty rooms, as they can clutter your map and get boring and repetitive quickly.

• Leave Room for Expansion: Unless you’re certain you don’t want to return to your dungeon, allow for places to expand later for future adventures. A tunnel running off the edge of the map, a flight of stairs leading down, or a large pit can all lead the way to new areas.

• Avoid Symmetry: Refrain from creating symmetrical dungeons in which one half is an exact mirror image of the other— it's unrealistic, and the players might be disappointed when they realize that they only have to explore half of a dungeon to see it all.

• Vary Room Shapes: Instead of just a bunch of rectangles, include strangely shaped rooms, alcoves, multilevel rooms, irregular caverns, and other variations. You can look at maps of real-world locations to get some ideas.

• Use Wide Corridors: Remember that combat in Pathfinder is based on 5-foot squares. If you fill your dungeon with 5-foot-wide hallways, you might end up with combats in which some of the heroes or monsters can’t actually get into the fight!

• Don't Make a Maze: Avoid the temptation to make your map into a maze- exploring one gets old quick once you're playing, especially if you spend most of your time during the game drawing twisted corridors on your mat when you could be running combat!

Finishing the Map

Once you're happy with your map, inking in the pencil lines makes the map a lot easier to read. You can use a fat-tipped pen to draw solid walls. Thinner pens are great for drawing doors and map symbols. Adding color (whether with pens or colored pencils) makes your map even easier to read. Number each room so you can easily refer to it in your notes. If possible, use a pen of a different color from anything else on your map so the number tags are easy to see.

If you have a computer and scanner, you can scan your map and then use an image-editing program to refine it. This is handy if you make an error on the map with ink and need to fix things. Details such as furniture, fire pits, pillars, and so on add a touch of realism to inhabited dungeons, but you can also add these when you draw it on a battle grid if you feel comfortable doing so on the fly.

Once you've finished your map, you can upload it to your VTT of choice and add walls, lights, or tokens as you see fit. Even a hand-drawn map can work perfectly well in a digital environment- just be sure to supplement it with descriptions of the rooms to breathe some life into your creation!

Strange Rooms

If you’re having a hard time coming up with ideas for your map, you can take ideas from “Menace under Otari,” or use some of these classic ideas.

  • Monster barracks full of filthy straw nests.

  • Narrow ledge overlooking a chasm.

  • Natural chimney in the rock that the heroes can climb up to reach a higher level.
  • Ancient library covered in dust.
  • Long hallway with rows of statues or suits of armor.
  • Sewer chamber blocked by gates on each side, with the levers to open them in another room.
  • Feasting hall with a large fire pit in the center.
  • Pens where guard animals are kept.
  • Museum with art made of permanent illusions.
  • Don't forget the latrines!

Environments.name: Environments
Environments.text:
Environment rules bring the locales your party travels through to life. You can often just use common sense as you run the game in different environments, but you need special rules for ones that really stand out. The entries below provide rules for special types of terrain, plus a few suggestions of sensory details you can add in as the heroes explore that environment. Many places have elements from multiple environments—for example, a snow-covered mountain might use both the arctic and mountain environment rules. The DCs here are typical ones provided for convenience. You can change the DCs as needed, using the normal rules for setting @UUID[.7ki36LtGrCjGHugy], and you can always choose to use just the environment rules that work best for your game.

Many adventures take place in dungeons—underground strongholds, warrens, or crypts that have become the dens of dangerous creatures. A dungeon could be constructed or naturally occurring, but either way, it combines the features of underground and urban environments found below. Regardless, your adventure can be set anywhere!

Aquatic

Aquatic environments are among the most challenging for heroes, short of other worlds and unusual dimensions.

• Swimming: Athletics skill to @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.c8TGiZ48ygoSPofx]{Swim}(DC 10 for still water, 15 for flowing water, and 20 for swiftly flowing water).

• Currents: Ocean currents, flowing rivers, and similar moving water are @UUID[JournalEntry.OoPjlnYYGLn5KPZy.JournalEntryPage.hYwHTbxIwLVsCIhJ#difficult-terrain] for a creature swimming against the current. If a creature’s in a current at the end of its turn, it moves a certain distance depending on the speed of the current (usually 5 feet or 10 feet). For instance, a 10-foot current moves a creature 10 feet in the current’s direction at the end of that creature’s turn.

Descriptions

Sights: choppy water, rolling waves, sunlight glinting, the curve of the horizon, driftwood

Sounds: waves lapping against a ship, seabirds' cries, fluttering sails, creatures breaching the surface

Smells: salt water, crisp fresh air, dead fish

Textures: frigid water, slimy seaweed, crusty salt collecting on surfaces

Arctic

The main challenge in an arctic environment is the low temperature, as described in the @UUID[.mhP6TyghfJ6AE3ia] journal, but arctic environments also contain ice and snow.

• Ice: Acrobatics skill to @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.M76ycLAqHoAgbcej]{Balance} without falling down (DC 12).

• Snow: Difficult terrain.

Descriptions

Sights: blinding reflected sunlight, snowy plains, distant glaciers, deep crevasses, rocky cliffs, ice floes and bergs, animal tracks in snow

Sounds: howling winds, drips of melting ice, utter quiet

Smells: clean air, half-frozen bog, lichen, seaweed

Textures: crunching snow, hard ice

Weather: frigid gales, light snowfall, pounding blizzard

Desert

Desert encompasses both sandy and rocky deserts as well as rugged badlands.

• Rubble: Rocky deserts are strewn with rubble, which is difficult terrain. Rubble dense enough to be walked over rather than navigated through requires Acrobatics to @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.M76ycLAqHoAgbcej]{Balance}as well (DC 15).

• Sand: Packed sand doesn’t impede movement, but loose sand is difficult terrain. Especially deep or loose sand requires a creature crossing it to use Acrobatics to Balance (DC 20).

Descriptions

Sights: blinding reflected sunlight, rolling dunes, a mirage, circling vultures

Sounds: rustling winds, cascading sand, insects at night

Smells: dust, desert herbs

Textures: coarse sand, warm rock, dry brush

Weather: direct heat, dust devil, sandstorm

Forest

These environments include jungles and other wooded areas.

• Trees: Athletics to @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy]{Climb} a tree (DC 15). Trees that take up an entire 5-foot square on the map (or more) are big enough to provide standard cover; narrower trees don’t.

• Undergrowth: Difficult terrain. Heavy undergrowth gives standard cover to anyone in it, but it’s even harder to move through. Each square costs 10 extra feet of movement, not just 5!

• Vines: Acrobatics or Athletics skill to swing on a vine (DC 15).

Descriptions

Sights: towering trees, dense undergrowth, verdant canopies, colorful wildlife, dappled sunlight through the trees, mossy tree trunks, twisted roots

Sounds: rustling leaves, snapping branches, animal calls

Smells: decomposing vegetation, flowering plants, pine trees, earthy mushrooms

Textures: leaves crunching underfoot, scraping branches, water dripping from above, rough bark

Weather: still air, cool shade, sporadic breeze, rain on the canopy, branches coated in thick snow

Mountain

Mountain environments also include hills, which share many aspects of mountains, though not their more extreme features.

• Chasms: Athletics to make a @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.JUvAvruz7yRQXfz2]{Long Jump} across a chasm or similar natural pit (DC 15 for a chasm 10 feet across; add 5 to the DC for every 5 feet wider). Failing to make the jump means taking bludgeoning damage from the fall equal to half the distance fallen. Alternatively, creatures can take the safer but slower route of Climbing down the near side of the chasm and then ascending the far side to get across. Good depths for chasms are 30 feet or 50 feet. Much deeper, and the fall is likely to kill a hero!

• Cliffs and Slopes: Athletics to @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy]{Climb} a cliff (DC 10 for sloped cliffs, 15 for steep cliffs, or 20 for sheer cliffs or steep ones with few handholds). Without extensive safety precautions, such as having a creature farther up secure a rope, a critical failure can result in significant falling damage.

• Lava: A volcano might have small lava flows. Just the heat from being near lava is harmful, dealing 1d6 fire damage each round to anyone within 10 feet. Going into the lava is almost certain death for anyone not immune to fire. It deals 20d6 fire damage every round!

• Rubble and Scree: Difficult terrain. Especially deep or pervasive rubble requires Acrobatics to @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.M76ycLAqHoAgbcej]{Balance} as well (DC 15).

• Undergrowth: Difficult terrain. Thick undergrowth on mountains is rare and follows the rules found under forests.

Descriptions

Sights: bare cliffs, snow caps, hardy trees, slopes littered with scree, fallen rocks, birds flying on currents, fog among the peaks

Sounds: howling wind, falling rocks, clear echoes, crunch of rocks underfoot, distant avalanche

Smells: blowing dust, pine trees, fresh snow

Textures: rough stone, powdery snow, unstable rubble

Weather: swirling clouds, chill of high altitude, direct sunlight, powerful wind and rain

Plains

The plains environment encompasses grasslands, such as savannas and farmland. Such terrain is usually fairly flat and easy to traverse.

• Undergrowth: Difficult terrain. Thick undergrowth in plains is rare (usually planted hedges or tall crops like corn) and follows the rules found under forests.

Descriptions

Sights: grass waving gently, scattered wildflowers, rocky outcroppings or boulders, the curve of the horizon

Sounds: rustling wind, birdsong, distant sounds carried far

Smells: fresh air, earthy soil, distant carcasses

Textures: touch of tall grass, rasp of scrub brush, crunch of dry dirt

Weather: cooling of gentle wind, heat of direct sunlight, massive black thunderclouds

Swamp

Wetlands are the most common kind of swamp, but this category also includes drier marshes such as moors.

• Bogs: Shallow bogs are difficult terrain for Medium creatures. Squares in deep bogs cost Medium creatures 10 extra feet of Speed per square, not just 5! If a bog is deep enough that a creature can’t reach the bottom, the creature has to use Athletics to Swim (DC 12).

• Undergrowth: Difficult terrain. Heavy undergrowth gives standard cover to anyone in it, but it’s even harder to move through. Each square costs 10 extra feet of movement, not just 5!

Descriptions

Sights: lush leaves, clouds of gnats, algae-coated water, shacks on stilts, darting fish

Sounds: croaking frogs, chirping insects, bubbling waters, splashing

Smells: rich moss and algae, pungent swamp gases

Textures: pushing through floating detritus, tangling creepers, thick mud

Weather: oppressive humidity, still air, pouring rain, rays of sunlight

Underground

Most underground environments consist of caves and other natural formations. Artificial dungeons and ruins combine underground features with urban features, like stairs and walls. Deep underground vaults have some of the same terrain features as mountains, such as chasms and cliffs.

• Cliffs and Slopes: Athletics to @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy]{Climb} a cliff (DC 10 for sloped cliffs, 15 for steep cliffs, or 20 for sheer cliffs or steep ones with few handholds). Without safety precautions like a creature farther up securing a rope, a critical failure can result in significant falling damage (bludgeoning damage equal to half the distance fallen).

• Floors: Natural cavern floors are rarely flat. They tend to have abrupt changes in elevation that are difficult terrain or require using Acrobatics to @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.M76ycLAqHoAgbcej]{Balance} (DC 10 or 12).

• Ledges: Moving across a narrow ledge requires using Acrobatics to Balance (DC 12).

• Magma: Caverns deep underground might have magma flowing within. Just the heat from being near magma is harmful, causing 1d6 fire damage each round to anyone within 10 feet. Going into the magma is almost certain death for anyone not immune to fire. It deals 20d6 fire damage every round!

• Rubble: Difficult terrain. Especially deep or pervasive rubble requires Acrobatics to Balance on when crossing it as well (DC 17).

• Walls: Athletics to Climb a natural cave wall (DC 20). Since most caves are formed by water, cave walls are often damp, making the DC 22 or 25.

Sights: winding passages, sputtering yellow torchlight, uneven or cracked floors, ancient writings or architecture, stalagmites and stalactites

Descriptions

Sounds: dripping condensation, scurrying rats or insects, distant clunks of machinery, tinny echoes of your voices and footsteps

Smells: staleness of still air, sulfur, tang of metal deposits

Textures: rough rock walls, stone smoothed by erosion, cobwebs

Weather: chill of underground air, geothermal heat

Urban

Urban environments include open city spaces as well as buildings. The building information in this section also applies to ruins and constructed dungeons.

• Crowds: Crowded thoroughfares and similar areas are difficult terrain. You might allow a creature to persuade a crowd to part and allow it to pass using Diplomacy, Intimidation, or Performance.

A crowd exposed to an obvious danger, like a fire or a rampaging monster, attempts to move away from the danger as quickly as possible, but a crowd is slowed by its own mass. A fleeing crowd typically moves at a Speed of 25 feet, potentially trampling or leaving behind slower-moving members of the crowd.

• Doors: Opening a door takes an Interact action. Locked doors require a creature to use Thievery to @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.2EE4aF4SZpYf0R6H]{Pick a Lock}. The DC and number of successes required to open the lock depend on the quality of the lock. Remember that a critical success is worth two successes!

• Rooftops: Flat roofs are easy to move across. Angled roofs require creatures to use Acrobatics to @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.M76ycLAqHoAgbcej]{Balance} (DC 13) or, if they’re especially steep, Athletics to Climb (DC 13).

Hurtling from roof to roof often requires using Athletics for a @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.JUvAvruz7yRQXfz2]{Long Jump}, though some buildings are close enough to Leap between. A High Jump might be necessary to reach a higher roof.

• Sewers: Sewers are generally 10 feet or more below street level and are equipped with ladders or other means to ascend and descend. Raised paths along the walls allow sewer workers access, while channels in the center carry waste. Sewers grates require 2 or more Interact actions to open, though they might be locked using the rules for locked doors above.

• Stairs: Difficult terrain for creatures moving up them, normal for creatures moving down.

• Walls: Athletics to @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy]{Climb} (DC 18 for a constructed stone wall, DC 20 for a brick wall).

Descriptions

Sights: milling crowds, domesticated animals, multi-story buildings, trash blowing in the streets

Sounds: town criers, shouting children, rattling wagon wheels

Smells: freshly baked bread, chimney smoke, industrial fumes, perfume, sewage

Textures: smooth cobblestones

Weather: rain on the rooftops

In Otari

These details are especially pronounced in @UUID[JournalEntry.sgxbTVNpwJ0jWBvw].

Descriptions

Sights: docked boats laden with fish, lumber sliding down the road toward the dock

Smells: caught fish, freshly cut lumber

Sounds: sawmill blades whirring

Weather.name: Weather
Weather.text:
Weather can be combined with @UUID[.AJZOnRliAzq7nbDM] to establish a mood or to make more memorable encounters. Weather can impose circumstance penalties on certain checks, from -1 to -4 based on severity.

Fog

Fog imposes a circumstance penalty on visual Perception checks: -1 for light fog or -2 for heavy fog. Creatures viewed through significantly thick fog have the @Compendium[pf2e.conditionitems.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} condition. You decide the distance of that concealment, but it’s usually around 30 feet for a light fog and 15 feet for a heavy fog.

Precipitation

Precipitation includes rain, snow, sleet, and hail. Wet precipitation douses flames, and frozen precipitation can create areas of snow or ice on the ground. Drizzle or light snowfall has little mechanical effect beyond limited visibility.

Most forms of precipitation impose circumstance penalties on vision-based Perception checks, usually a -1 circumstance penalty or -2 for heavier precipitation. Hail often is sparser but loud, instead causing a -2 circumstance penalty on hearing-based Perception checks. Especially heavy precipitation, such as a downpour of rain or heavy snow, might make creatures concealed if they’re far away.

Thunderstorms

High winds and heavy precipitation accompany many thunderstorms. There’s also a very small chance that a creature might be struck by lightning during a storm. A lightning strike usually deals [[/r 5d6 #electricity]] electricity damage.

Temperature

In most places, even if it’s very cold or hot, the weather isn’t actively dangerous. However, temperatures of 105º F and above or 12º F or below can be harmful! For every hour spent in temperatures from 105º to 114º, a creature takes [[/r 1d6 #fire]] fire damage. For every hour spent in temperatures from -21º to 12º, a creature takes [[/r 1d6 #cold]] cold damage. Temperatures beyond those ranges are too dangerous for characters of levels 1-3.

Wind

Wind imposes a penalty on Perception checks to hear and on physical ranged attacks such as arrows. This circumstance penalty is -1 for a weak wind or -2 for a stronger wind. Powerful windstorms can make physical ranged attacks impossible! Wind snuffs out handheld flames. Particularly strong winds might require a creature to succeed at a DC 15 Athletics check each time it attempts to move. On a failure, the creature doesn’t move on that action, and on a critical failure, it’s knocked back 5 feet and falls prone. Any moderate or strong wind is difficult terrain for a flying monster moving against the wind.

Downtime.name: Downtime
Downtime.text:
When the heroes return home or otherwise aren’t adventuring, they’re in downtime. This is their time to do everyday activities, such as buying gear. You might not have any downtime in your games at all! If the heroes do have some time off between adventures, just ask the players to spend a few minutes describing what their heroes do in that time. You probably won’t need to roleplay any scenes. Downtime is a bigger focus of the full Pathfinder game since the choices the heroes make carry across all 20 levels of play.

Two things heroes can likely do during downtime are shop for magic items and rest long enough to recover from ailments. A hero who does nothing but rest for a full 24-hour period recovers Hit Points equal to double their Constitution instead of the normal amount from an 8-hour rest. Heroes above 1st level multiply this amount by their level.

Character Creation.name: Tworzenie postaci
Character Creation.text:
Czy jesteś gotowy na przygodę? Pierwszą rzeczą, którą musisz zrobić, jest stworzenie swojego bohatera! Do ciebie należy wyobrażenie sobie przeszłych doświadczeń, osobowości i światopoglądu bohatera - to przygotuje scenę do odgrywania ról podczas gry.

Tworzenie postaci

PF2E System Wiki: Tworzenie bohatera @UUID[JournalEntry.qFSLpCM2cpRQWCR2.JournalEntryPage.WpWULbveo4SMmMj5]

Karty postaci

Pierwszym krokiem jest zdobycie karty postaci. Jeśli tworzysz nowe postacie, MG może utworzyć dla ciebie nowe karty, klikając "Utwórz aktora" w zakładce "Aktorzy" na pasku bocznym. Będą musieli również przypisać aktora do ciebie, co można zrobić, klikając go prawym przyciskiem myszy i nadając ci uprawnienie „Właściciel” w sekcji „Konfiguruj uprawnienia”.

Jeśli przydałyby ci się wskazówki dotyczące nauki czytania i korzystania z kart postaci systemu Pathfinder Second Edition, możesz skorzystać z wiki systemu, do której link znajduje się powyżej, aby zapoznać się z polami i zakładkami, które ma do zaoferowania, a także z kilkoma konkretnymi poradami dotyczącymi grania określonymi klasami.

Przydatne narzędzia

Podczas tworzenia postaci lub później, gdy będziesz awansować swojego bohatera, będziesz dodawać atuty, atuty, przedmioty, zaklęcia i inne cechy do swojego arkusza postaci. System zawiera wszystkie te dane dla ciebie - musisz tylko zastosować je do swojej postaci!

W zakładce „Kompendia” na pasku bocznym, na dole, znajduje się przycisk „Przeglądarka kompendiów”. Po kliknięciu otwiera się interfejs, który umożliwia wyszukiwanie i filtrowanie całej zawartości reguł zawartych w systemie. Możesz go użyć do szybkiego znalezienia cech, które chcesz wybrać, a następnie przeciągnąć je z tego okna na swój arkusz postaci. To takie proste!

Zasady tworzenia postaci

W niektórych miejscach zasady lub opcje postaci przedstawione w pliku PDF Pathfinder Beginner Box mogą różnić się od tych używanych na tych stronach dziennika lub w systemie PF2E. Wynika to z faktu, że Beginner Box przedstawia uproszczony i usprawniony zestaw zasad, aby ułatwić naukę systemu.

Ponieważ wirtualny stół radzi sobie z wieloma drobiazgami i złożonością, które wynikają z nauki mechaniki nowego systemu gry, zdecydowaliśmy się trzymać pełnych zasad opisanych w Pathfinder Second Edition Core Rulebook.

Możesz jednak odnieść się do pliku PDF z pudełkiem dla początkujących, jeśli zamiast tego chcesz grać według tych zasad. Jeśli nie jesteś pewien, gdzie powinieneś szukać, zapytaj swojego MG. Po zapoznaniu się z zasadami, możesz skorzystać z opisanych tutaj kroków, aby pokierować swoim procesem!

Pathfinder Society

Jeśli planujesz poprowadzić przygodę Menace Under Otari w ramach zorganizowanej rozgrywki Pathfinder Society, szczególnie ważne jest, abyś wziął pod uwagę, której wersji zasad używasz do tworzenia postaci. Jeśli jeszcze tego nie zrobiłeś, zajrzyj na stronę dziennika @UUID[JournalEntry.qFSLpCM2cpRQWCR2.JournalEntryPage.WpWULbveo4SMmMj5], aby dowiedzieć się więcej.

Step By Step.name: Krok po kroku
Step By Step.text:
Etapy tworzenia postaci zostały tutaj przedstawione w sugerowanej kolejności, prowadząc cię przez wczesne etapy historii życia twojego bohatera, ale możesz je ukończyć w dowolnej kolejności. Na przykład, możesz wiedzieć, że chcesz grać czarodziejem, zanim zdecydujesz, że czarodziej będzie elfem!

Każdy krok zawiera instrukcje dotyczące wypełniania pól w arkuszu postaci. Arkusz postaci został zaprojektowany tak, aby był łatwy w użyciu podczas gry, ale tworzenie bohatera odbywa się w innej kolejności, więc będziesz poruszać się tam i z powrotem po arkuszu postaci podczas przechodzenia przez proces tworzenia postaci. Dodatkowo, arkusz postaci zawiera wszystkie pola, których możesz potrzebować, nawet jeśli nie wszyscy bohaterowie będą mieli coś do wpisania w każdym z nich. Jeśli jakieś pole w arkuszu postaci nie dotyczy twojego bohatera, pozostaw je puste.

Krok 1: Tworzenie koncepcji

Jakim bohaterem chcesz grać? Odpowiedź na to pytanie może być tak prosta, jak „dzielny wojownik” lub tak skomplikowana, jak „dziecko elfich wędrowców, ale wychowane w mieście zdominowanym przez ludzi i oddane Sarenrae, bogini słońca”.

Zastanów się nad osobowością swojego bohatera, napisz kilka szczegółów na temat jego przeszłości i zastanów się, po co mu ta przygoda.

Krok 2: Modyfikatory atrybutów

Zanim zaczniesz dokonywać wyborów, musisz zapoznać się z @UUID[.FovwsmUiYCMzsfVm]. Modyfikatory atrybutów wpływają na prawie wszystko, co robi twoja postać, więc jest to dobry moment, aby określić, które atrybuty będą najważniejsze dla twojego bohatera.

Na razie modyfikatory atrybutów zaczynają się od +0, ale będą zwiększane w miarę postępów w kolejnych etapach tego poradnika. Powinieneś śledzić je na swojej karcie postaci. Za każdym razem, gdy jeden z twoich wyborów daje ci premię do umiejętności, zwiększasz modyfikator umiejętności o +1.

Krok 3: Wybierz pochodzenie

Czy twój bohater jest wytrzymałym krasnoludem, pełnym gracji elfem czy wszechstronnym człowiekiem?

Pochodzenie twojej postaci określa, który lud nazywa swoim własnym, niezależnie od tego, czy są to różnorodni i ambitni ludzie, wyspiarskie, ale żywe elfy, czy tradycjonalistyczne i skupione na rodzinie krasnoludy. Pochodzenie twojej postaci może być kluczową częścią jej tożsamości, kształtować sposób, w jaki postrzega świat i pomóc jej znaleźć w nim swoje miejsce - lub to, przeciwko czemu się buntuje!

Aby dowiedzieć się więcej na temat trzech zalecanych początkowych pochodzeń poniżej, kliknij na ich nazwę, aby otworzyć materiały informacyjne na ich temat.

Możesz również dowiedzieć się więcej o mechanicznych konsekwencjach swojego pochodzenia, czytając stronę dziennika Pochodzenie.

Po wybraniu, Twoje pochodzenie automatycznie zastosuje większość funkcji lub bonusów, ale nie może dokonywać wyborów za Ciebie! Zanim przejdziesz dalej, upewnij się, że:

  • Dodałeś swoje pochodzenie do karty postaci.
  • Przydzieliłeś darmowe premie do atrybutów i zdecydowałeś, czy bierzesz dobrowolną wadę.
  • Wybrałeś dziedzictwo z listy zalecanych opcji lub jedno z innych dziedzictw dostępnych w systemie.
  • Wybrałeś atut pochodzenia, który reprezentuje umiejętność nabytą przez bohatera w młodym wieku.

Krok 4: Wybierz przeszłość

Przeszłość bohatera może reprezentować jego wychowanie, zdolności, które doskonalił od młodości lub inny aspekt jego życia, zanim został poszukiwaczem przygód. Przeszłość bohatera poprawia jego modyfikatory atrybutów i zapewnia specjalną zdolność.

Poniższe przeszłości są dobrym wyborem dla wielu różnych postaci, ale wiele innych jest dostępnych w różnych publikacjach Pathfinder Second Edition i można je znaleźć w @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.pf2e-macros.s2sa8lo9dcIA6UGe]. Możesz dodać je do swojej karty postaci po prostu przeciągając je na nią.

@Compendium[pf2e.backgrounds.CAjQrHZZbALE7Qjy]{Akolita} @Compendium[pf2e.backgrounds.9lVw1JGl5ser6626]{Przestępca} @Compendium[pf2e.backgrounds.IObZEUz8wneEMgR3]{Pokładowy} @Compendium[pf2e.backgrounds.SOmJyAtPOokesZoe]{Parobek} @Compendium[pf2e.backgrounds.o1lhSKOpKPamTITI]{Księgowy} @Compendium[pf2e.backgrounds.r0kYIbN06Cv8eNG3]{Wojownik}

Krok 5: Wybierz klasę

Klasa daje bohaterowi zestaw heroicznych umiejętności i określa jego rolę w walce. Każda klasa zapewnia dodatkowe opcje, które pozwalają ci zdecydować, jakim typem bohatera chcesz być! Czy zagrasz oddanym klerykiem, potężnym wojownikiem, przebiegłym łotrzykiem czy pilnym czarodziejem?

Aby dowiedzieć się więcej o niektórych klasach postaci, kliknij poniższe łącza. Możesz również przeczytać stronę dziennika@UUID[.NpFrnwOBAFYATF1A], aby dowiedzieć się więcej o tym, czym zajmują się klasy.

Podobnie jak w przypadku Pochodzenia, bardzo ważne jest zapoznanie się ze szczegółami swojej klasy, aby upewnić się, że nie zapomniałeś dodać żadnych bonusów do swojej karty.

  • W zależności od wybranej klasy, otrzymasz premię do swojego kluczowego atrybutu - mądrości dla kleryków, siły lub zręczności dla wojowników, zręczności dla łotrzyków i inteligencji dla czarodziejów.
  • Twoja klasa określa również liczbę @UUID[JournalEntry.OoPjlnYYGLn5KPZy.JournalEntryPage.nQgj1rvfQhLtlspj] i języków, z którymi zaczynasz, oprócz tych przyznanych przez twój modyfikator inteligencji (który zostanie dodany w ostatnim kroku, @UUID[.BEtnPZeVzTcELPDf]).
  • Niektóre klasy, takie jak łotrzyk, mogą przyznać ci atut na pierwszym poziomie.
  • Jeśli jesteś klerykiem, nie zapomnij wybrać swojego @UUID[.FfuaIRGpgOEd8Jwr]!

Krok 6: Zakup sprzętu

Postać rozpoczyna grę na pierwszym poziomie z 15 sztukami złota do wydania na podstawowe wyposażenie. Aby sprawdzić, w jakich broniach i pancerzach twoja postać jest wytrenowana, przejdź do zakładki Umiejętności na karcie postaci i spójrz na swoje umiejętności.

Jeśli wiesz, które przedmioty chciałbyś kupić lub chciałbyś je przejrzeć, możesz otworzyć przeglądarkę kompendiów na dole zakładki Kompendia na pasku bocznym i wyszukać je tam lub zapoznać się z kopią Pathfinder Core Rulebook.

Zestawy klasowe

Jeśli chcesz szybko zacząć, rozważ wybór jednego z poniższych „zestawów klasowych”, które szybko zapewnią ci przydatny zestaw wyposażenia dla twojej klasy. Aby to zrobić, po prostu przeciągnij jeden z nich do swojego ekwipunku.

Niektóre z tych zestawów klasowych dają ci kilka możliwości wyboru, takich jak broń, którą możesz preferować jako wojownik - możesz przeczytać ich opisy w celu uzyskania dodatkowego kontekstu.

@UUID[Item.BCSVb3hhyFw4ppus] @UUID[Item.RwtG2QiqkxWBVHOY] @UUID[Item.Xo6PWwcrCh8CLJe0] @UUID[Item.nVpkugq6jfoamhve]

Krok 7: Ukończ swojego bohatera

Ostatnim krokiem w tworzeniu bohatera jest obliczenie jego statystyk na podstawie dokonanych wyborów. Porada ta znajduje się na następnej stronie - @UUID[JournalEntry.KIpNnMtah73eyPC8.JournalEntryPage.BEtnPZeVzTcELPDf].

Pregenerated Heroes.name: Wygenerowani bohaterowie
Pregenerated Heroes.text:
Beginner Box został zaprojektowany do użytku z następującymi czterema kultowymi postaciami, z których każda będzie doskonałym wyborem dla nowych graczy lub tych, którzy chcą od razu wskoczyć do akcji:

Można je znaleźć w zakładce „Bohaterowie” na pasku bocznym po prawej stronie ekranu.

Aby dowiedzieć się więcej o tym, jak grać kultowymi postaciami lub aby pomóc ci zdecydować, którą z nich zagrać, możesz przeczytać opisy każdej klasy, które kończą się streszczeniem ich historii.

Inne postacie

Jeśli chcesz rozszerzyć wybór przy swoim stole, każdy z bohaterów poziomu 1 z kompendium Ikony będzie dobrym wyborem. Jednak niektórzy z nich mogą mieć bardziej skomplikowane klasy lub cechy niż te zawarte w pudełku dla początkujących.

Ponadto zawsze możesz stworzyć własnych bohaterów od podstaw. W takim przypadku zapoznaj się ze stroną dziennika @UUID[.RRxNZiD64dvvpWYt]. Będziesz musiał dostarczyć własne tokeny dla tych bohaterów lub wybrać jeden z kilku ogólnych tokenów dołączonych do tego świata. MG znajdzie je w plikach modułu, pod adresem:

pf2e-beginner-box/assets/portraits-heroes

Leveling Up.name: Awansowanie na wyższy poziom
Leveling Up.text:
Przeżywając przygody, pokonując przeciwników i rozwiązując wyzwania, twoja postać zdobywa punkty doświadczenia (PD). Śledź swoje PD na arkuszu postaci w miarę ich zdobywania.

Po osiągnięciu 1000 PD zdobywasz poziom! Zwiększ swój poziom o 1 i odejmij 1000 PD od aktualnego poziomu PD. (Wszelkie dodatkowe PD możesz zachować na kolejny poziom!) Następnie zapoznaj się z opisem swojej klasy, aby dowiedzieć się, jakie korzyści przyniosło ci awansowanie na wyższy poziom.

Awansowanie na wyższy poziom w Foundry

@JournalEntry[KIpNnMtah73eyPC8]{Tworzenie bohatera}

Zwiększanie poziomu

Kiedy awansujesz, najpierw zwiększ swój poziom na karcie postaci. System Pathfinder Second Edition dla Foundry automatycznie doda kilka funkcji i zdolności w oparciu o twoją klasę. Ta lista nie jest ostateczna i nie może dokonywać wyborów, takich jak zwiększanie umiejętności lub atutów, ale powinna pomóc ci zaoszczędzić trochę czasu!

Dokonywanie wyborów

Jeśli przejdziesz do zakładki atutów, powinieneś zobaczyć, że pojawiły się pewne sloty. Na przykład, jeśli osiągniesz poziom 2, pojawi się miejsce na atut klasy 2. poziomu. Te sloty na atuty mogą być pomocne w informowaniu o tym, gdzie i kiedy należy dokonać wyboru. Aby je zapełnić, możesz skorzystać z przeglądarki kompendium, aby wybrać atuty dostępne dla twojej klasy i poziomu, jak wyjaśniono we wpisie @JournalEntry[KIpNnMtah73eyPC8]{Tworzenie bohatera}, do którego link znajduje się powyżej. Po dokonaniu wyboru, wystarczy przeciągnąć go z przeglądarki kompendium do pustego miejsca na atut.

Podobnie, możesz także użyć przeglądarki kompendium, aby wybrać nowe zaklęcia lub znaleźć inne funkcje, które nie zostały automatycznie dodane do twojej karty.

Finishing your Hero.name: Ukończenie bohatera
Finishing your Hero.text:
Zidentyfikowałeś już główne aspekty swojego bohatera. Teraz nadszedł czas, aby dodać ostatnie szlify!

Niniejszy poradnik stanowi ostateczną kontrolę, aby upewnić się, że nie zapomniałeś o żadnych ostatnich szczegółach, a także listę elementów wykończeniowych, takich jak imię i osobowość bohatera. Czy twój bohater jest czempionem sprawiedliwości, czy sprzedajnym handlarzem, który pracuje dla każdego, kto może zapłacić rachunki?

Punkty Atrybutów

Teraz, gdy dokonałeś już wszystkich wyborów w ramach tworzenia postaci, powinieneś ponownie spojrzeć na swoje punkty @UUID[.FovwsmUiYCMzsfVm], aby upewnić się, że nie zapomniałeś wybrać żadnego ze swoich wzmocnień.

Atuty

Podobnie, twoje pochodzenie lub klasa mogły przyznać ci pewne atuty. Sprawdź powiązaną zakładkę w swoim arkuszu postaci - czy są jakieś puste miejsca na atuty, które możesz wypełnić?

Umiejętności

Premia do inteligencji bohatera określa liczbę umiejętności, które zna, oprócz tych, które zyskał dzięki swojej przeszłości i klasie. Z pełnej listy @UUID[JournalEntry.OoPjlnYYGLn5KPZy.JournalEntryPage.nQgj1rvfQhLtlspj] wybierz liczbę umiejętności równą modyfikatorowi Inteligencji twojego bohatera, które chcesz wytrenować. Oznacz je jako wytrenowane, klikając przycisk biegłości w zakładce Umiejętności na karcie postaci.

Imię i zaimki

Nie zapomnij nazwać swojego bohatera i zdecydować o jego zaimkach - postacie wszystkich płci lub bez płci mają takie same szanse na zostanie poszukiwaczami przygód. Zapisz imię i zaimki bohatera w górnej części arkusza postaci. Jeśli chcesz, możesz także załączyć obrazek przedstawiający wygląd bohatera lub opisać jego wygląd w tej sekcji.

Deities.name: Deities
Deities.text:
Any character can worship a deity, though the choice is most important for @UUID[.MBKCQnQp9I44q46X]. As a cleric, the deity you choose gives you specific benefits. Enter your choice of deity onto your character sheet.

The following deities are good choices to start with. If you'd like to learn more about any of them, click on their name for more information.

@Compendium[pf2e.deities.JgqH3BhuEuA4Zyqs]{Desna} is the butterfly goddess of dreams, luck, and travel. As her cleric, you swear to aid fellow travelers, explore new places, express yourself through art and song, and find what life has to offer. You also promise never to cause fear or despair or engage in bigoted behavior.

Also known as the Dawnflower, @Compendium[pf2e.deities.BNycwu3I21dTh4D9]{Sarenrae} is the goddess of healing and the sun. As her cleric, you swear to protect allies, provide aid to the sick and wounded, and help repentant creatures seek redemption. You promise never to create undead, lie, or fail to strike down evil.

@Compendium[pf2e.deities.sZrdzh0ANQnZGXJb]{Torag} is the dwarven god of crafting and defense. As his cleric, you swear to be honorable and forthright, keep your word, respect the forge, and serve your people. You promise never to tell lies, cheat someone, intentionally create inferior works, or show mercy to the enemies of your people.

Choosing an Ancestry.name: Choosing an Ancestry
Choosing an Ancestry.text:
The other pages of this journal offer a brief overview of three of the most iconic ancestries available. It's up to you whether you'd like to play as one of those three, or any of the other ancestries that are available in Pathfinder Second Edition.

Once you've made your choice, you need to apply it to your character. You can do this by clicking on the + icon near the Ancestry field of your character sheet and choosing it from the options there. You can also click on one of the Ancestries in the list to learn more about the mechanical benefits and drawbacks it applies.

Ancestry Benefits

When you choose an ancestry, your character sheet will automatically be populated with the basic features and benefits granted by your ancestry. Other benefits may require you to make a choice between several options.

Ancestries determine your hero's Speed, Size, and starting Hit Points. They also usually grant languages.

Senses

Some ancestries have supernatural senses, such as the ability to see in the dark. If your ancestry grants you such a feature, it should appear on the main tab of your character sheet automatically. Note that some heritages can modify or improve the acuity of these senses, too.

Ability Boosts

Each ancestry provides a combination of set Ability Boosts, free Ability Boosts, and sometimes Ability Flaws which represent that ancestry's basic capabilities. The ways in which Ability Boosts are managed are outlined in the @UUID[.lygt82lIvFJVGsUA] journal page.

Heritages

After you've chosen an Ancestry, you'll also choose one of the ancestry's heritages, which expand on your character's origins and abilities. You can only have one Heritage, and you can't change your choice later.

You can choose a heritage in the same way that you chose your ancestry, or you can take one of the recommended options for each ancestry which are detailed in the associated pages of this journal. Either way, make sure to read the description of your heritage so that you understand which benefits it is providing to you.

Some heritages can be taken by members of any Ancestry. These are called Versatile Heritages. For instance, a member of any ancestry could be born with traces of fiendish blood in their veins, and so Tieflings are a versatile heritage. As well as the other benefits of a Heritage, a Versatile Heritage also offers you an expanded pool of options when choosing Ancestry Feats.

Ancestry Feats

Every hero chooses an Ancestry Feat at first level. You can find your feat slots by going to the Features tab, under the Ancestry Feat header. There should be an empty slot, which you can fill in two ways. You can drag an ancestry feat into that slot to choose it, or you can press the magnifying glass icon to open up the compendium browser with some helpfully preconfigured filters.

Note that if you chose a Versatile Heritage, you may also be able to choose feats from your Heritage as well as from your Ancestry.

Dwarf.name: Dwarf
Dwarf.text:
Dwarves are well-known as a stoic and stern people who dwell deep underground in cities built into the hearts of the mightiest mountains. They are fierce on the battlefield, holding the line against charging orcs or taking the fight to towering giants. Dwarves stand about a foot shorter than most humans, and most take pride in braiding or styling their hair.

Playing a Dwarf

Choose the @Compendium[pf2e.ancestries.BYj5ZvlXZdpaEgA6]{Dwarf} ancestry by dragging it onto your character sheet. This will automatically apply several of the features associated with the Dwarf ancestry to your character, some of which are explained here.

Hit Points: Dwarves are hardy and can take a lot of punishment. You start with 10 hit points from your ancestry.

Speed: Dwarves are slower than most- their starting Speed is only 20.

Darkvision: Dwarves can see exceptionally well, even in total darkness.

Names

Dwarves honor their children with names taken from ancestors or dwarven heroes, and it's quite rare to invent a new name or to borrow a name from another culture for a child.

Sample Names: Agna, Bodill, Dolgrin, Edrukk, Grunyar, Ingra, Kazmuk, Kotri, Lupp, Morgrym, Rogar, Rusilka, Torra, Yangrit

Dwarven Heritages

Like for most folk in the world, there are many different family lines of dwarves, all with their own traditions and specialties.

Each heritage grants benefits which reflect your character's past, education, and experiences. If you need some help, we suggest you pick one of the following heritages.

@Compendium[pf2e.heritages.VTtXwBxrfRUXSL38]{Death Warden Dwarf}

Your ancestors have been tomb guardians for generations, and the power that they cultivated to ward off necromancy has passed on to you.

@Compendium[pf2e.heritages.5CqsBKCZuGON53Hk]{Forge Dwarf}

You are well adapted to hot environments, and you know about quality weapons because of the time you and your ancestors put in working at hot forges.

@Compendium[pf2e.heritages.VSyOvtgJ1ZNpIVgC]{Rock Dwarf}

Your ancestors lived and worked among the great ancient stones of the mountains or the depths of the earth.

Elf.name: Elf
Elf.text:
As an ancient people, elves have the perspective that can come only from watching the arc of history. The world has changed around them, and they struggle to reclaim their ancestral homes, most notably from terrible demons that have infested their lands. Though renowned for their grace, beauty, and knowledge, they place far more importance on personal freedom.

Playing an Elf

Choose the @Compendium[pf2e.ancestries.PgKmsA2aKdbLU6O0]{Elf} ancestry by dragging it onto your character sheet. This will automatically apply several of the features associated with the Elf ancestry to your character, some of which are explained here.

Hit Points: Elves are slender and slightly frailer compared to other ancestries. You start with 6 hit points from your ancestry.

Speed: With their long legs and easy grace, elves are a bit faster than people of most ancestries. Your starting Speed is 30.

Low-Light Vision: Elves can see well in dim light. This makes it easier for you to target creatures that are in shadow.

Names

An elf keeps their personal name secret from those outside their family, giving a nickname when meeting other people. This nickname can change over time, due to events in the elf's life or even on a whim. An elf might be known by many different names to associates of varying ages and regions. Elven names consist of multiple syllables and are meant to flow lyrically- at least in the Elven tongue.

Sample Names: Aerel, Amrunelara, Caladrel, Dardlara, Faunra, Heldalel, Jathal, Lanliss, Oparal, Seldlon, Soumral, Talathel, Tessara, Variel, Yalandlara, Zordlon

Elf Heritages

Like for most folk in the world, there are many different kinds of elves, hailing from different regions and families. Pick one of the following heritages and write it in the Heritage area under your ancestry . Then add its abilities to your character sheet.

Elves can live for hundreds of years, and after spending enough time in one locale, they adapt to match their surroundings. Their skin and hair can even change, such as woodland elves taking on the colors of the trees and leaves around them. Therefore, many elf heritages are connected to the environments in which they live. We suggest you pick one of the following heritages.

@Compendium[pf2e.heritages.NfIAGatB1KIzt8G7]{Cavern Elf}

You were born underground or spent many years in tunnels or caverns where light is scarce. Your eyes are exceptionally well adjusted to the dark.

@Compendium[pf2e.heritages.1wVDYY9Wue0G5R9Q]{Whisper Elf}

Your ears are finely tuned, able to detect even the slightest whispers of sound.

@Compendium[pf2e.heritages.nW1gi13E62Feto2w]{Woodland Elf}

You're adapted to life in the forest or the deep jungle, and you know how to climb trees and use foliage to your advantage.

Human.name: Human
Human.text:
As unpredictable and varied as any of Golarion's peoples, humans have exceptional drive and the capacity to endure and expand. Though many civilizations thrived before humanity rose to prominence, humans have built some of the greatest and most abhorrent societies throughout the course of history. Today they are the most populous people in realms around the world.

Playing a Human

Choose the @Compendium[pf2e.ancestries.IiG7DgeLWYrSNXuX]{Human} ancestry by dragging it onto your character sheet. This will automatically apply several of the features associated with the Human ancestry to your character, some of which are explained here.

Hit Points: Humans are not as sturdy as dwarves, nor as frail as elves. You have 8 hit points from your ancestry..

Speed: Humans move about as quickly as most ancestries. You have a speed of 25 from your ancestry.

Names

Unlike many ancestral cultures, which generally cleave to specific traditions and shared histories, humanity's diversity has resulted in a near-infinite set of names. Humans' names are as varied as their beliefs and appearances.

Human Heritages

Like for most folk in the world, there are many different kinds of humans.

Each heritage grants benefits which reflect your character's past, education, and experiences. If you need some help, we suggest you pick one of the following heritages.

@Compendium[pf2e.heritages.hFBwsVcSnNCJoimo]{Versatile Heritage}
You embody the ambition of humanity and constantly seek to better yourself.
@Compendium[pf2e.heritages.zVf0Hlp5xG0Q7kmc]{Skilled Heritage}
Your ingenuity allows you to learn a wide variety of skills.

Choosing a Class.name: Choosing a Class
Choosing a Class.text:
The other pages of this journal offer a brief overview of four of the most iconic classes available. It's up to you whether you'd like to play one of those four, or any of the other classes that are available in the Pathfinder Second Edition ruleset.

Once you've decided on the best class for you, you need to apply it to your character. You can do this by clicking on the + icon near the Class field of your character sheet and choosing it from the options there.

Class Benefits

When you choose a class, your character sheet will automatically be populated with the basic features and benefits granted by your class. Other benefits may require you to make a choice between several options.

If you ever are uncertain what your class is granting you, you can open your class item and read the full list of features and benefits that it contains from the main tab of your character sheet. However, you may find the way that the information is presented in the core rulebook for Pathfinder Second Edition to be more legible. We will try to offer an overview here, but when in doubt, refer back to the rulebook!

Attribute Boosts

Choosing a class will automatically grant you an attribute boost to that class's "key ability". For some classes, like Wizard, this is set- for others, you get a choice.

In addition, at this point you'll also be given the opportunity to take four free attribute boosts. These can be to any attribute modifier of your choice, although they must each be assigned to a different attribute.

All of these attribute boosts can be managed in the same ways as any other, as outlined in the @UUID[.lygt82lIvFJVGsUA] journal page.

Proficiencies

Your class will grant you training in certain weapons, armor, and skills. These can be viewed from the "skills" tab of your character sheet.

In addition, your class will grant you the ability to choose a number of additional skills and languages. We'll make these choices later, during the @UUID[JournalEntry.KIpNnMtah73eyPC8.JournalEntryPage.BEtnPZeVzTcELPDf] section, but don't forget about them!

Features

The "features" tab of your character sheet is where class features and class feats will appear. Once you add your class, the basic features will be listed here, and more will populate this tab as your character levels up. Take a moment to familiarise yourself with them.

Some classes can choose class feats immediately at level 1, while others will have to wait until later. As with Ancestry feats, a slot will appear for them when you have a new choice to make.

Spellcasting

Some classes are spellcasters, which means that they'll need to use the Spells tab of their character sheet.

Creating spellcasting entries and adding spells to them is not something that the system will do automatically for you. However, the rules that detail how your character interacts with magic and how their spellcasting works will be included in the class feature that granted you spellcasting. From there, you should be able to populate your Spells tab.

Choosing spells can be one of the most exciting parts of playing a spellcaster. When you have a spellcasting entry, you can click the magnifying glass icon to open the Compendium Browser to a pre-filtered list of spells that are valid choices for that level. Do note though that, unless your GM gives you special permission, you probably can't choose any of the options with a rarity of Uncommon or higher!

Cleric.name: Cleric
Cleric.text:
Blessed with divine magic, you live the ideals of your faith, adorn yourself with the symbols of your church, and train diligently with your deity’s favored weapon. Your spells might protect and heal your allies, or they might punish foes and enemies of your faith, as your deity wills.

Play a Cleric If You Want To...

  • Support and heal your allies with divine spells.
  • Fight with the favored weapon of your deity.
  • Know about religious writing and images.
  • Oppose and destroy evil undead creatures.

During Combat Encounters...

You balance between casting spells and attacking with weapons—typically the favored weapon of your deity. Most of your spells can boost, protect, or heal your allies.

While Exploring...

You detect nearby magic and interpret any religious writing or icons you come across. You might also concentrate on a protective spell for your allies in case of attack. After a battle or hazard, you might heal anyone who was hurt.

The Iconic Cleric: Kyra

@Actor[yoAU5rWYH4KJGPr5]{Kyra}

Kyra is a priestess of @Compendium[pf2e.deities.BNycwu3I21dTh4D9]{Sarenrae}, a sun goddess who teaches her followers to heal the wounded and destroy evil. Kyra grew up admiring the beautiful stained glass of Sarenrae's temple and the graceful priestesses who practiced with their scimitars each dawn.

When bandits attacked Kyra's village, those priestesses fought to the death to protect the villagers, but the bandits were too many and the village burned. Kyra was one of the few survivors, and on the smoking ruins of the beautiful temple she swore her life and sword arm to Sarenrae, promising to protect those who could not protect themselves and to slay those who would harm the innocent.

Kyra has a fierce will, and is proud of her faith and her skill with the scimitar.

Fighter.name: Fighter
Fighter.text:
Whether you fight for honor, greed, loyalty, or simply the thrill of battle, you’re an undisputed master of weaponry and combat techniques. You might have been a knight, mercenary, or blade master. Whatever the case, you’ve honed your martial skills into an art form, performing devastating attacks on your enemies.

Play a Fighter If You Want To...

  • Use the biggest weapons— or two at once!
  • Fight on the front lines.
  • React quickly to enemy actions.
  • Wear the best armor and carry a shield.
  • Frighten or bully your foes.

During Combat Encounters...

You strike with unmatched accuracy and use specialized combat techniques. You stand between allies and enemies, attacking foes who try to get past.

While Exploring...

You keep up your defenses in preparation for combat and stay vigilant for hidden threats. You also overcome physical challenges in your way, breaking down doors, lifting obstacles, climbing adeptly, and leaping across pits.

The Iconic Fighter: Valeros

@Actor[vcwqnXHkhzFhrt7O]{Valeros}

Valeros was a month away from an arranged marriage to a farmer's daughter when he realized he didn't want to be tied down to one place for his entire life.

He left in the middle of the night with a change of clothes, some food, and an axe handle for a weapon. He fell in with mercenaries who taught him how to wield a sword and wear heavy armor, but his good heart made him not want to work for cheats, swindlers, and sadists. He became an adventurer, making his own decisions about whom he'd fight and why.

Valeros is friendly and brave. Though he sometimes gets in over his head and throws himself into battle with too much gusto, he's smart and doesn't let people talk to him like he's a brute. He is loyal to his friends, fond of a good mug of ale, and happiest when in the company of women.

Rogue.name: Rogue
Rogue.text:
Using your wits and quick reactions, you take advantage of your opponents' missteps to strike where it hurts most. You seek thrills and test your skills, and you likely don’t care much for any laws that happen to get in your way. While every rogue follows a unique path, the one thing you all share is the breadth and depth of your skills.

Play a Rogue If You Want To...

  • Sneak up on foes to deal more damage.
  • Steal things without being seen.
  • Excel at a variety of skills.
  • Use trickery to solve problems during adventures.

During Combat Encounters...

You move about stealthily so you can catch foes unawares. You're a precision instrument, more useful against a tough boss or distant spellcaster than against rank-and-file soldiers.

While Exploring...

You sneak about to get the drop on foes and scout for danger or traps. You're a great asset, since you can disable traps, solve puzzles, and anticipate dangers.

The Iconic Rogue: Merisiel

@Actor[czQ0MaZBu3BqMpce]{Merisiel}

Merisiel is an elf who grew up as an orphan among humans. She is a master at stowing away on ships and has called dozens of cities home, leaving one place for another after her human companions grew old and she stayed young. Merisiel has never met a problem that couldn't be solved with a knife in one way or another. But when stabbing's not the best solution, she makes up for it by being incredibly agile and skilled with small objects, such as lockpicks.

Merisiel's life experiences have taught her to enjoy things in the moment and to their fullest-it's impossible to tell when the good times might end. She's open and expressive with her thoughts and emotions, and while she's always on the move and working on her latest batch of schemes for easy money, in the end all her plots come down to being faster than everyone else-either on her feet, or with her beloved blades. She wouldn't have it any other way.

Wizard.name: Wizard
Wizard.text:
You're an eternal student of the universe's arcane secrets, using your mastery of magic to cast powerful and devastating spells. You treat magic like a science and study esoteric tomes to understand how magic works.

Play a Wizard If You Want To...

  • Cast spells to devastate foes and protect allies.
  • Gain a deeper understanding of the schools of magic than any other class.
  • Influence the world around you and solve problems with your magic.

During Combat Encounters...

You likely try to stay out of the fray, carefully judging when to use your spells. You save your most powerful magic to incapacitate threatening foes and use your reusable spells against weaker enemies.

While Exploring...

You locate magical auras and determine the arcane significance of magical writing or phenomena you uncover. When you run across an unusual obstacle, you probably have a scroll or spell that should make it easier to overcome.

The Iconic Wizard: Ezren

@Actor[WNX5OQKPh4uaV7mW]{Ezren}

Ezren was raised as a younger son of a successful spice merchant. He enjoyed the comforts of a well-to-do family, lived in a neighborhood that was relatively free of crime, and had no lofty ambitions. However, when the church of the merchant god accused his father of heresy and corruption, ruining the family business, Ezren was determined to prove his father's innocence. To his shock, the church's accusations were true. Outraged, Ezren left his home and began studying magic on his own, as no wizard would take a 40-year-old as an apprentice. Now he wants to travel the world and make a difference in other peoples' lives.

Ezren is skeptical of human nature, instead putting his trust in his own brilliant intellect and magical abilities.

Attribute Modifiers.name: Attribute Modifiers
Attribute Modifiers.text:
Attribute modifiers represent your hero’s raw potential. They influence almost every other statistic on your character sheet.

Strength

Strength measures your hero’s physical power. Strength gets added to attack and damage rolls in hand-to-hand combat.

Dexterity

Dexterity measures agility, balance, and reflexes. Add Dexterity to attack rolls with ranged weapons, AC, and Reflex saving throws.

Constitution

Constitution measures your hero’s overall health and stamina. Constitution is added to your Hit Points and Fortitude saving throws.

Intelligence

Intelligence measures how well your hero can learn and reason. A high Intelligence determines how many skills your hero has.

Wisdom

Wisdom measures your hero’s common sense, awareness, and intuition. Wisdom is added to your Perception and Will saving throws.

Charisma

Charisma measures your hero’s personal magnetism and strength of personality. A high Charisma helps your hero influence other people.

Modifying Attributes.name: Modifying Attributes
Modifying Attributes.text:
Attribute Boosts

Several of the choices you make at character creation will grant you an Attribute Boost. This means you should increase the associated Attribute modifier by one- for instance, from +0 to +1.

Sources of Attribute Boosts

You gain attribute boosts from your Ancestry, your Background, and your Class. In addition, you gain four free attribute boosts that you can place anywhere you wish (although not twice in the same ability score).

Attribute Flaws

In addition to a boost, our Ancestry might also come with an Attribute Flaw, such as a malus to charisma for dwarves. You also have the option of reducing two of your attribute modifiers by 1 each to increase a third by 1, which is called a "Voluntary Flaw". Because this choice is made at the same time as your ancestry, it cannot be used to boost an attribute modifier which is already increased by your ancestry. Likewise, the flaw cannot be applied to an attribute which is already being reduced by your ancestry.

Attribute Boosts on Foundry

PF2E System Wiki: Making a PC

The PF2E system on Foundry VTT makes it very simple to increase your ability scores as you build your character. Clicking on the Edit button next to your ability scores on your character sheet opens up a window which allows you to allocate your boosts and flaws. Any attribute boosts that are automatically granted by your ancestry or other choices you have made will be listed here, and any free boosts you have available can be selected from all legal options.

In addition, because the system automatically calculates and applies the appropriate modifiers for you, you will see your rolls account for your attribute modifiers without you needing to add them up yourself.

Ability Scores in the Beginner Box.name: Ability Scores in the Beginner Box
Ability Scores in the Beginner Box.text:
Ability Scores in the Beginner Box

PF2E System Wiki: Making a PC @UUID[JournalEntry.KIpNnMtah73eyPC8.JournalEntryPage.RRxNZiD64dvvpWYt]

As mentioned in the Creating Your Hero handout, the specifics of character building can vary wildly between the core rules and the more streamlined rules included within the Beginner Box. As always, if there is any doubt, make sure to ask your GM which version of the rules you're using, and to consult the rulebooks directly to get the facts straight from the source. The Pathfinder Second Edition system for Foundry operates under the assumption you are playing with the core rules. If you are using the Beginner Box rules, the information contained within these journal handouts and the class item's "details" tab may not apply to your character.

One of the ways in which the Beginner Box streamlines the core rules is by removing the concept of an ability score. Instead, Ability Boosts directly increase your modifier. As such, at times, the Beginner Box might tell you to increase your ability modifier by one. This is equivalent to an Ability Boost and should increase your ability scores by 2- it does not mean that you increase your score by one (for example, from 10 to 11).

Actions.name: Actions
Actions.text:
A hero affects the world by using actions. Some actions, called basic actions, can be used by anyone—@Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.BlAOM2X92SI6HMtJ]{Seek}, @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.Bcxarzksqt9ezrs6]{Stride}, and @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.VjxZFuUXrCU94MWR]{Strike} are all basic actions. Others, like spells and special abilities, can be used only by certain characters. Each action produces an effect. Some do this automatically, but for others you’ll roll to determine the effect.

Action Icons

You’ll see the following icons used for the different types of actions found throughout the game.

1 Single actions are the simplest and most common actions. You can use 3 single actions on your turn, in any order you want.

r Reactions are special actions that you can use when it isn’t your turn. Each reaction has a trigger that specifies when you can use that reaction. You can use only 1 reaction per round.

Activities take longer than a single action. Activities that use 2 actions have this symbol: 2. Activities that use 3 actions—your whole turn—have this symbol 3. Some activities take even longer, and you can use them only when you’re between combat encounters.

Basic Actions

Every creature can do common tasks using basic actions. You’ll @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.pvQ5rY2zrtPI614F]{Interact}, @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.UHpkTuCtyaPqiCAB]{Step}, @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.Bcxarzksqt9ezrs6]{Stride}, and @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.VjxZFuUXrCU94MWR]{Strike} a great deal. Many feats and other actions tell you to use one of these basic actions or modify them to produce different effects. For example, a large number of activities include a Strike.

As long as you can act, you can also speak without spending any actions. You can usually speak a single sentence or so per round. Sign language works the same way, but you need free hands to do it, and the recipient of your message needs to see you rather than hear you. Special uses of speech, such as attempting a Deception skill check to @Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.ewwCglB7XOPLUz72]{Lie}, require spending actions and follow their own rules.

Actions While Exploring

When you’re not in an encounter, you don’t have to track when you get your 3 actions and reaction, though you can still use actions and reactions as needed. The GM tells you how much time you have to get things done and determine what actions and reactions you can use if there’s confusion. Activities with the exploration trait take a long time to carry out, so you can use them only outside of encounters.

Areas.name: Areas
Areas.text:
Some effects occupy an area of a specified shape and size. There are three types of areas: bursts, cones, and lines. Usually, an ability with an area affects everyone in the area. For instance, if you cast the @Compendium[pf2e.spells-srd.y6rAdMK6EFlV6U0t]{Burning Hands} spell, everyone in its cone- friend or foe!- must attempt a Reflex save, and if they fail, they take fire damage. A creature that's inside the area but totally behind a barrier, such as on the other side of a wall from your area's origin, isn't affected by the effect.

Burst: A sphere expanding out from the center. You can set the center of the burst on any grid intersection in range.

Cone: A quarter-circle shoots out from you. Choose whether to aim the cone straight out from you or diagonally when you use the ability.

Line: A straight line shoots from a corner of your square in a direction you choose.

Measured Templates

Knowledge Base: Measurement and Templates

Foundry VTT provides a useful Templates feature that allows you to place area effects. There are template shapes for circles, cones, rectangles, and rays- covering all of the needs of the Pathfinder system. In addition, many of the spells in Pathfinder Second Edition come preconfigured with their areas, and will have a button in the spellcard that allows you to easily place a template!

If you'd like to place a template manually, you can also use "Measurement Controls" from the toolbar. Templates that you place are automatically colored to match your assigned player color.

To delete a template that you have placed, simply hover over its placement icon and press delete.

Carrying and using Items.name: Carrying and using Items
Carrying and using Items.text:
You can carry items in three ways: held, worn, or stowed. Held items are in your hands. You can hold one item in each hand or one two-handed item using both hands. Worn items are tucked into pockets, belt pouches, bandoliers, weapon sheaths, and so forth. You can retrieve a worn item with a single action, and putting it back uses another action. As usual, manipulating objects uses the Interact basic action. You can drop an item without spending an action. Stowed items are in a backpack or a similar container, and you have to spend an action to take off the backpack before you can spend the Interact action to retrieve an item stowed within.

Held Items in Foundry

You can control how an item your character owns is held or worn by clicking on the hand icon beside it in your inventory, which allows you to choose between held, worn, dropped, and so on. Setting an item as "held" will enable certain functions, like making the weapon's strike appear on your actions tab, or creating a light effect in the case of a torch.

Many ways of using items require you to spend multiple actions. For example, making a Strike with a dagger worn in a sheath at your belt requires using an Interact action to draw the dagger and then using a second action to Strike. Likewise, you have to draw a potion from your pocket or belt pouch before you can Interact to drink it.

Hands

Each item’s entry on the table says how many hands it takes to use the item. Most items that require two hands can be carried in only one hand, but you must spend an Interact action to change your grip in order to use the item. The GM may determine that an item is too big to carry in one hand (or even two hands, for particularly large items).

Wearing Tools

You can make a toolkit (such as a climbing kit or healer's toolkit) easier to use by wearing it. This allows you to draw and replace the tools as part of the action that uses them. Any toolkits not worn in this manner must be stowed or taken out with an Interact action.

Currency and Expenses.name: Currency and Expenses
Currency and Expenses.text:
The standard form of currency in Pathfinder is coinage, which comes in three types: copper pieces (cp), silver pieces (sp), and gold pieces (gp). A silver piece is worth 10 cp and is the standard for most everyday transactions. Gold pieces are often used for purchasing magic items and other expensive items, as 1 gold piece is worth 10 sp or 100 cp.

Buying and Selling

As you gain experience and additional wealth, you should periodically buy new equipment. You might also find equipment or even magic items during your adventures, or you can buy them once you have enough money. You can usually buy equipment only in settlements; the GM will let you know when it’s time for a shopping spree!

You can also sell equipment you aren’t using anymore. Most items can be sold for half their Price, but broken shields can’t be sold at all.

Cost of Living

The table below shows how much it costs to get by. These values cover room and board, taxes, and other fees.

Standard of Living

Week

Month

Subsistence

4 sp

2 gp

Comfortable

1 gp
